in-person seminar or other discussion format

Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.

What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: This is a very comprehensive course providing detailed materials for estimation, hypothesis testing and large sample theory.

Very rigorous overview of the basics of statistical inference - the course is formally split into two units of "finite sample theory" (minimax, Bayes, Neyman-Pearson, etc.), and then "asymptotic theory" (CLT, delta method, MLEs, local alternatives, fisher information, etc).

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
Strength: Organized course materials, detailed and clear explanations and proofs of theorems by Professor Fan, definitely learned a lot from this course.
Weakness: There were only lecture notes wrote by hand during lecture. Sometimes it's a little hard to read.

The design of the course absolutely forces you to learn the material at a high level. Problem sets are not easy, even if you have a solid peer group to work with. If you are taking this course concurrently with other difficult/time-consuming ones, you should expect there to be at least one or two problem sets that you are simply unable to complete on time. Exams are similarly difficult - the median on the midterm this year was a 45%. 

All of the above is made bearable by the fact that Zhou Fan is an excellent, clear, and kind instructor. He motivates all of the material he covers extremely well, and you leave the class genuinely feeling that you've learned a great deal of statistics.

One distinct weakness: Multiple students felt that Jiyi (TA) was remarkably unhelpful in office hours and email correspondence. The addition of Tianhao (other TA) midway through the semester was a lifesaver in that regard. Do not take this course if Jiyi is the only TA.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: TAs and Professor's office hours are very helpful. Professor would pause in the middle of the lecture to ask if there were questions.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Definitely! You never want to miss this class if you want to pursue a PHD later.

Yes - if you are looking for a truly rigorous treatment of inference, there really is no other option. Simply be prepared to work hard, and understand that it is normal for talented undergraduates to struggle in this course (as do the 25+ graduate students).
